comments.html: Checked what vPTX does. It does enter routes from all protocols in the routing table (the thing you can check with show route) like FRRouting, but it does not create BGP entries out of OSPF entries just for the fun of it, like SR Linux does.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Both seem to operate roughly the same way in terms of how redistribution is configured. You need to redistribute in a policy from one protocol to the other, no 'redistribute' commands or 'network' statements. That much of it I kind of like.

Juniper has a default deny though. Unless you explicitly export "from protocol OSPF" to BGP then it doesn't happen. I think that's better tbh, but I guess it just means on SRL you need to make sure to have sensible policies everywhere.
comments.name: Cathal Mooney

comments.html: My point is that there is no BGP RIB. There is a single RIB. Juniper does not show you OSPF routes when you use "show route protocol bgp" because "protocol bgp" means the source of the route is BGP. I think that SR Linux is just using a different presentation of the RIB when you use "show protocols bgp route" to display attributes relevant to BGP.
comments.name: Vincent Bernat

comments.html: It does not seem that alien. I think this is the same for Juniper (there are attributes as source protocol and advertising protocol, "show route protocol bgp" and "show route advertising-protocol bgp") and for BIRD (same, "show route protocol X" and "show route export X").
comments.name: Vincent Bernat
